blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> explicit queue(const Alloc&);

discussion.p: This will be implemented like so:

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> explicit queue(const Alloc& a) : c(a) {}

discussion.p: The issue is that Alloc can be anything that a container will construct from, for example an int. Is this intended to compile?

blockquote.pre: queue<int> q(5);

discussion.p: Before the addition of this constructor, queue<int>(5) would not compile. I ask, not because this crashes, but because it is new and appears to be unintended. We do not want to be in a position of accidently introducing this "feature" in C++0X and later attempting to remove it.
I've picked on queue. priority_queue and stack have the same issue. Is it useful to create a priority_queue of 5 identical elements?
discussion.note: Daniel, Howard and Pablo collaborated on the proposed wording.

blockquote.p: Move to Ready.

resolution.note: This resolution includes a semi-editorial clean up, giving definitions to members which in some cases weren't defined since C++98. This resolution also offers editorially different wording for , and it also provides wording for .

blockquote.p: The container adaptors each take a Container template parameter, and each constructor takes a Container reference argument. This container is copied into the Container member of each adaptor. If the container takes an allocator, then a compatible allocator may be passed in to the adaptor's constructor. Otherwise, normal copy or move construction is used for the container argument. [Note: it is not necessary for an implementation to distinguish between the one-argument constructor that takes a Container and the one- argument constructor that takes an allocator_type. Both forms use their argument to construct an instance of the container. — end note]

blockquote.pre: explicit queue(const Container& cont);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with cont.

blockquote.pre: explicit queue(Container&& cont = Container());

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(cont).

blockquote.pre: queue(queue&& q)

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(q.c).

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> explicit queue(const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with a.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> queue(const container_type& cont, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with cont as the first argument and a as the second argument.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> queue(container_type&& cont, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(cont) as the first argument and a as the second argument.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> queue(queue&& q, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(q.c) as the first argument and a as the second argument.

blockquote.pre: queue& operator=(queue&& q);

blockquote.p: Effects: Assigns c with std::move(q.c).
Returns: *this.

blockquote.pre: priority_queue(priority_queue&& q);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(q.c) and initializes comp with std::move(q.comp).

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> explicit priority_queue(const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with a and value-initializes comp.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> priority_queue(const Compare& compare, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with a and initializes comp with compare.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> priority_queue(const Compare& compare, const Container& cont, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with cont as the first argument and a as the second argument, and initializes comp with compare.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> priority_queue(const Compare& compare, Container&& cont, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(cont) as the first argument and a as the second argument, and initializes comp with compare.

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> priority_queue(priority_queue&& q, const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(q.c) as the first argument and a as the second argument, and initializes comp with std::move(q.comp).

blockquote.pre: priority_queue& operator=(priority_queue&& q);

blockquote.p: Effects: Assigns c with std::move(q.c) and assigns comp with std::move(q.comp).
Returns: *this.

blockquote.pre: stack(stack&& s);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(s.c).

blockquote.pre: template <class Alloc> explicit stack(const Alloc& a);

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with a.

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with cont as the first argument and a as the second argument.

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(cont) as the first argument and a as the second argument.

blockquote.p: Effects: Initializes c with std::move(s.c) as the first argument and a as the second argument.
